subanswer.text:
Filter versus Map Explanation using Sieve Algorithm Implementation:

In programming, `filter` applies a function to each element in an iterable (such as lists) and returns those elements that satisfy some condition (return true); it does not change them directly but creates new filtered items based on the conditions provided. On the other hand, `map` takes a single input argument -a function—and also processes every item in an iterable; however, unlike 'filter', ‘map’ transforms/returns results without filtering out unacceptable entries. 1.subquestion: According to Vieta's formulas, how does the sum of the roots relate to the coefficient $a_{n-1}$?

subanswer.text: By Vieta's formulae applied here, since $a_n=2$, $$-\tfrac{a_{n-1}}{a_n} =\sum _i r_i=r_1+..+r_n.$$Thus $$\begin{array}{|c|ccccc}\hline & |&a_{n-1}&|\leq&\quad &&&& \\ -\frac{|a_{n-1}|}{|2|}&=& &\textstyle {\displaystyle\;\\&\scriptsize {r}_1+\dotsb +\;{\displaystyle\,} } &=& \;66 \\ &&&&&\qquad &&&||\\ &&&&& || && |\end{array}$$From which follows immediately (by Suppose the polynomial

Given that $a_n=2$ and $a_0=66$, what is the least possible value of $|a_{n-1}|$?

ost_step.1: By Vieta's formulas, the product of the roots of $f(x)$ taken one pair at a time equals $\frac{-a_{n-1}}{a_n}=-\frac{a_{n-1}}{2}$.
ost_step.2: Suppose the smallest absolute value among the distinct integer roots occurs twice; call it $r$. If so, every other root differs from $r$ by some nonzero amount or zero difference. Let those differences add up to $k$.

direct_answer.text: We know that the constant term -$a_{n-1}/2$ takes both signs (+/-); let us assume without loss of generality that $a_{n-1}\geq 0.$ Thus each set of three consecutive terms $\{a_j,a_{j+1},a_{j+2}\}$ whose first element matches either sign adds no more than another full copy of r (either as itself or negative (-r)). Hence any such triple contributes nothing new beyond multiples of |r| . Furthermore since f(0)=$\pm\ a_{n-1}$, neither does { } contribute anything further besides possibly changing the parity of {-a_{n-1}}.
